Summary: I'm sorry, but the provided hotel reviews do not contain information about fine dining options at the 3 West Club. The reviews focus on location, value, cleanliness, and basic amenities.
This hotel is near Restaurant Row, but has no restaurant. There are hundreds of ethnic restaurants on the doorstep.
The hotel has a Thai restaurant called Kittichai. The breakfast options were good and there were some excellent bars on site.

6 Columbus has a popular Japanese/sushi restaurant, Blue Ribbon Sushi & Grill, in the lobby that is open late and also provides room service and traditional American breakfast. The bar at Blue Ribbon Sushi is highly rated with good bartenders and the food is considered good, particularly the fried chicken.

The hotel has a bar/restaurant, Silverleaf Tavern, which offers tasty appetizers, cocktails, and wines by the glass; the Silverleaf Tavern's breakfast was considered good by some, although room service menus are thought to be priced beyond comprehension. Michael Jordan's restaurant is located in Grand Central Station nearby.
The hotel has a lobby bar and access to room service from nearby restaurants, with a new restaurant called The Breslin opening soon. A complimentary breakfast of croissants and coffee is included.

The Affinia 50 does not have a restaurant but is near Smith & Wollensky's Steakhouse and various restaurants on 2nd Avenue, with room service from The Mint Indian restaurant. There are also options for breakfast nearby, including the NY Luncheonette and a breakfast buffet at the Kimberley Hotel.
The Barking Dog restaurant is next to the hotel. One reviewer recommended a Japenese restaurant and Artisanal, a wine/cheese bistro, a few blocks away.

The hotel does not have a bar or cafe, but it is possible to order from a number of places for room service, including Italian (Accamedia de Vino), American, and Chinese restaurants. Jojo's is down the road and Alice's Tea Cup is right next door.
Niles restaurant is connected to the hotel, and offers quick room service and breakfast. Many reviewers found it to be modern with attentive bar staff.

The Shelburne has an onsite bar and grill called Rare that is known for its burgers, and some reviewers found the food to be excellent with good service; Rossini's restaurant is also nearby. Breakfast at the hotel costs extra, and some reviewers found it to be pricey, though Rare offers a good menu.

The hotel also offers deep fried artichokes in the lounge.

The Salisbury Hotel has a restaurant directory of local restaurants that deliver, with Jean Georges and Robuchon a couple of blocks away. Across the street from the hotel is the Russian Tea Room, and next door is Angelo's Coal Oven Pizza Restaurant.
The San Carlos has an Indian restaurant called Mint, with room service available from there. Some reviewers also enjoyed dining at Oscar's in the nearby Waldorf Astoria.
I am sorry, but none of the reviews mention fine dining. The hotel is near many restaurants and bars.

The hotel has a lobby bar and Hudson's restaurant, but the hotel restaurants are often described as very expensive; Bobby Flay's Bar Americain is one block away. A few reviewers did recommend the hotel's club room breakfast, reporting healthy options.

The hotel has an attached restaurant and bar but many reviewers recommend eating elsewhere due to high prices, mixed food quality, and rude staff; nearby restaurants include City Lights Diner, City Lights Diner, Galaxy on 9th Avenue, 10th Ave Dinner, and Bis. Co. Latte. The breakfast is a buffet with some reviewers finding it good and reasonably priced while others found it mediocre, blaming someone else for the fact that it was out of just about everything.

The hotel restaurant was not yet open during the review period, but there are several restaurants nearby. Some reviews mention breakfast service in the bar area and room service, though prices were considered high.

The Sofitel has a restaurant and bar downstairs; some reviewers found the hotel restaurant expensive for breakfast, the food delicious, and with excellent service. The Gaby restaurant offers a lovely ambiance.

The Soho Grand has a lobby bar and restaurant with generally well-regarded food that is sometimes described as expensive. Breakfast is available, but some reviewers consider it underwhelming and prefer nearby options.
The hotel has a restaurant with fabulous food, but food was good, not exceptional. The main bar and club room were hardly used.
The hotel has a trendy bar/restaurant, Aspen Social Club, that serves light meals and breakfast. The restaurant is expensive, and there are other restaurants and cafes right on the doorstep.

The Alex Hotel has a restaurant called Riingo which serves sushi and has a Michelin star; Riingo's food was described as 'a picture on a plate' type of cuisine, well prepared, and pricey. However, some reviewers felt the food was overpriced and the drink service slow, and others recommended eating at delis and diners near the hotel due to the food costs.
The Belvedere is near Restaurant Row, and a Swiss restaurant called Mont Blanc is next door. The hotel is attached to a Brazilian steakhouse.
The hotel restaurant, Ocean 50, offers great breakfast, with one reviewer recommending skirt steak and mud cake. Room service food is considered above average and excellent by some reviewers.

The Blakely Hotel has an adjoining Italian restaurant, Abboccato, which is often busy and offers room service, a pre-theater prix fixe menu, and a bar. Several reviewers enjoyed meals at the restaurant, citing the food and wine pairings, though some found it pricey.

The hotel has an Italian restaurant called Gemma that serves breakfast, lunch and dinner, and is often busy with a hip crowd; room service is available from Gemma and the bar serves good cocktails. Some reviewers thought Gemma was fantastic, while others felt it was average and a bit overpriced.

The Bryant Park Hotel has an excellent Japanese restaurant called KOI, as well as a trendy bar called Cellar Bar. Koi offers room service and some reviewers said the room service was great from the Koi restaurant.

The Carlton Hotel has an in-house restaurant, Country, which some reviewers found delicious, gourmet-standard, trendy, and busy; breakfast pastries were once bakery fresh. The hotel also has a bar that some reviewers found nice and good for cocktails, though some found it overpriced, and one found the bar manager closed early if it was quiet.

The Carlyle has a formal restaurant requiring jackets at dinner, casual dining rooms, and the supper club Cafe Carlyle. The hotel breakfast buffet is adequate, and the Bemelmans Bar is a not-to-be-missed experience.

There is no bar or restaurant in the hotel itself, but the hotel has a connection to a restaurant nearby. Reviewers mention an excellent French restaurant, Cafe d'Alsace, about 3 blocks away and an Italian restaurant, La Cucina, across the street.

The hotel has a restaurant/bar called Bourbon Street downstairs that serves amazing food, with many other restaurants with live music nearby on Restaurant Row. The hotel has connections to many of the local bars in the Times Square area.
This hotel is located in Chelsea, near many restaurants, and offers room service from numerous restaurants. There is no restaurant or bar located in the hotel.
The reviews do not mention fine dining at the hotel. There are mentions of a diner on 9th and 34th and an Italian restaurant nearby.
This hotel does not have a restaurant, but is located near many restaurants. Some reviewers recommend Freeman's, Allen & Delancey, Sugar Diner, Katz's Deli, Russ & Daughters, and Lombardi's Pizza.
I am sorry, but none of the reviews mention fine dining at this hotel. The reviews focus primarily on the hotel's budget-friendly price, cleanliness, shared bathrooms, and location.
This hotel does not have its own restaurant but is close to many dining options. 44 1/2, Thalia, Uncle Nicks Greek Restaurant, Sombrero's Mexican and Cosmos Diner are mentioned as nearby restaurants.
I am sorry, there is no mention of fine dining at this hotel in the reviews.
The hotel restaurant, "Room with a View," has panoramic windows overlooking the park and has been recently renovated. The restaurant food was great, but pricey.

This hotel is a budget option in a central location, with no on-site restaurant but many dining options nearby, including Koreatown and a chocolate and wine restaurant next door. Some reviewers mention an Irish pub and the Cosmic Cafe for breakfast.
This hotel does not have a restaurant, bar, or room service, but there are bakeries next door and many Chinese restaurants nearby. A restaurant called Bacaro is a 2-minute walk away.

This hotel does not have a restaurant, but is close to many restaurants, including a Brazilian restaurant, Burger Joint in the Parker Meridian, Keen's and Joe's Shanghai. A bistro, db Bistro Moderne, is also nearby on 44th street.

The Inn at Irving Place offers Lady Mendl's Tea Salon, which serves a 5-course tea service in an opulent dining room. The hotel also features Cybar, a bar downstairs where cabaret singers perform and a buffet is served.

The Iroquois Hotel has an elegant restaurant on the premises called Triomphe, with a tasting menu, seasonal menu and bar. Some reviewers noted the restaurant is intimate, the service exceptional, and the food is of high standard.

The hotel has a bar and lounge area that attracts a huge line every night and a ballroom that is available for private parties. A cafe/coffee shop is opening soon in the lobby area and a restaurant is scheduled to be completed by Fall 2009.
The Kimberly has a steakhouse, George O'Neill's, which serves a breakfast buffet and is open until 2 am. Ferros next door offers a great Sunday buffet brunch.

The Lombardy does not have an on-site restaurant, but Table xII restaurant opens into the hotel and room service is available from a nearby restaurant. There are many restaurants and diners within a city block.

The London NYC offers fine dining at Gordon Ramsay's flagship restaurant in the States, with options for both a formal dining experience and a more casual cafe. Many reviewers highlight the quality of the food, though some found it pricey.

The Lucerne has an attached restaurant called Nice Matin, with Mediterranean food, a French bistro, that is popular with locals and offers room service. The hotel also gives a discount on breakfast at Nice Matin.
These reviews mention a pricey breakfast on-site, and the Redeye Grill across the street. The Carnegie and Stage Delis are also nearby.

The Mansfield has a cocktail bar/restaurant with a "relaxing yet sophisticated literary leather and cigar vibe" where breakfast is served. Breakfast is available in the bar which has "background light jazz music playing".

The Marcel is next door to Inoteca, a lively neighborhood bar/restaurant with a good cocktail bar that has a real New York feel. There are many restaurants and bars in the Gramercy/Flatiron area, both high end (Michelin rated) and more common.

The Maritime Hotel has an Italian restaurant, La Bottega, and a Japanese restaurant, Matsuri, with room service available from both. Some reviews praise the food in the restaurants, but others mention slow service.
The Mark Bar and restaurant are mentioned as wonderful. Complimentary breakfast was included in the price of the hotel.
I am sorry, but there is no mention of excellent fine dining in the provided hotel reviews.

Some reviews mention the hotel staff made restaurant recommendations and reservations. One review mentions the Italian restaurant Olana, but several reviews describe the included breakfast as basic with bread and cheese.

The Mercer has an excellent restaurant, Mercer Kitchen, that offers delicious food, including a tuna and wasabi pizza, and excellent service in a dark, chic atmosphere. Breakfast is also available in the lobby, and room service offers the full Mercer Kitchen menu.

The hotel has an upscale Italian restaurant called "Insieme," which some reviewers found very good, offering dishes like lasagna and lemon ricotta pancakes. However, some reviewers found the food and service soulless, and the restaurant is pretty spendy.

I am sorry, but the provided reviews do not contain information about excellent fine dining at the hotel. The reviews mention a continental breakfast, nearby diners, and restaurants but do not contain details about fine dining.

The Muse Hotel has a restaurant called The District which serves an amazingly-priced three-course pre-theater prix fixe menu and has a chef that likes to visit with guests. Some reviewers found the food excellent, but noted that the restaurant is pricey, has limited menus and service can be slow.

The New York Helmsley has a restaurant (Mindy's) that serves good food with mixed reviews and limited menus, while the lobby bar (Harry's Bar) offers pleasant drinks and bar food. The hotel is near multiple fine dining options within walking distance.

The New Yorker Hotel has an excellent diner and Coopers Tavern restaurant on the ground floor, though some found the Tick Tock Diner to be over-priced, and Coopers Tavern to be a little expensive. World Yacht Dinner cruise is recommended by at least one reviewer.
The hotel has a new restaurant called Caprice, a lobby bar, and Cafe Pierre. The dining room requires men to wear a jacket.

The Plaza has multiple dining options including the Oak Room restaurant, Champagne Bar, and Palm Court, though some reviewers found the food and service to be inconsistent and overpriced. Chef Eric Hara's staff and talents were praised by one reviewer who held their wedding reception in the Oak Room.
Le Bateau Ivre, a French bistro, is located next door and offers excellent service, food, and music. Morning Star Diner is nearby and recommended for a cheap and friendly diner experience.
The hotel offers room service, and a complimentary continental breakfast. Virgil's Barbecue and Cafe 123 are nearby.

The hotel has multiple food and drink servings a day in the club lounge, and BLT Market is the new dining room created by Laurent Tourarndel. Breakfast was delicious, though pricey, and the Star Lounge is fantastic for Afternoon Tea.
The Roosevelt has a restaurant, but reviewers state that the food is expensive. There is a bar in the hotel and offers room service.
The Sherry-Netherland offers room service from Cipriani's, and some suites have kitchens. Breakfast is included, though the restaurant was under renovation at one point.

The Shoreham has a bar and restaurant that serves moderately priced drinks and good food, with breakfast available, but the restaurant can be noisy and has lousy food. A continental breakfast is available, but it may not be worth the cost.
The St. Regis has Alain Ducasse restaurant for fine dining, as well as the Astor Court for afternoon tea or breakfast. The hotel also offers prix fixe lunch and dinner menus.
The Standard Grill is available for dining, with some reviewers noting good food and value. Breakfast, lunch, and dinner are served, with room service also available.

The hotel has an in-house restaurant, Cafe Boulud, with innovative dishes and attentive service, and the restaurant provides room service to hotel guests. The chef at Cafe Boulud has a Michelin star, and another restaurant in NY with three stars.

I am sorry, but the reviews provided do not contain information about fine dining at the Sylvan Guest House. The reviews focus on the guesthouse's location in Harlem, its proximity to subway lines, safety of the neighborhood, and the amenities of the apartments.

The hotel is attached to the Serefina restaurant, which offers a 20% discount to hotel guests and has good service, breakfast, and Italian fare; Carmines in Times Square is also nearby and recommended. The hotel restaurant was closed for renovations during some stays and at least one reviewer found the room service food not great.

The Waldorf Astoria has multiple dining options including Peacock Alley, Bull & Bear, and Oscar's, with some reviewers noting the restaurants are expensive but with high-quality food. Sunday brunch at Peacock Alley is mentioned as lavish but pricey at $95/person.
Shula's Steakhouse is located in the hotel, though some found it to be very expensive. Some reviewers enjoyed Shula's restaurant, noting the excellent quality of the food.

The hotel has an attached bar/restaurant that some reviewers found expensive or with slow service, and also indicates a lack of a bar. The Rainbow Rooms and Oyster Bar are specific mentions of nearby dining, and the Wyndham hotel is known for fine dining in the are
The hotel has a restaurant, Shang, with good food, though some found the service mediocre. Some reviewers also mentioned good nearby restaurants such as Rayuela and Kampuchea.
I am sorry, but there was no mention of fine dining at this hotel.
The hotel has a restaurant with good food and a Sunday brunch that is considered excellent. Some reviewers enjoyed room service, especially in the early hours, and found it excellent.

The Trump International Hotel offers fine dining at Jean-Georges, with some reviewers highlighting the quality of food and service. A casual dining option, Nougatine, is also available with food from the same kitchen as Jean-Georges.
The Tudor Hotel has a bar and a restaurant, though some found the bar to be pricey and the restaurant to be depressing. A few reviewers noted the breakfast was expensive and not worth the cost.
The Avalon has a restaurant, though reviews note it may be closed for refurbishment. Breakfast is available but may be pricey and service is inconsistent.

The hotel has an ICON restaurant, which is expensive but good, and the WETBAR has amazing drinks. Room service offers limited options after 11:30, but guests can order from the ICON restaurant's menu.

Some reviewers mention Audrey's for breakfast, the Wet Bar, or the bar in the neighboring W Court hotel, but availability and hours may vary. There's a small buffet in the bar downstairs and breakfast can be ordered in the room.
The hotel has a restaurant, Blue Fin, that serves seafood and sushi and is open for breakfast, lunch, and dinner. There is also a sushi bar on the ground floor and Benjamin's Steakhouse is nearby.

The W Union Square has an on-site restaurant, Olives, which is a Todd English establishment. Many reviewers enjoyed the food there, although some found it pricey and had issues with the restaurant being closed or the room service being mediocre.

The hotel has multiple restaurants, including the Bull and Bear steakhouse, Oscar's which offers many of the same tasty choices included on the room service menu, and a great Japanese restaurant on site. The food is generally considered delicious, though expensive, and room service is available.

The hotel is located near Stone Street eateries and Delmonico's, and offers room service from local restaurants. One reviewer had dinner at Fraunces Tavern, a historical tavern, one block from the hotel.

The Warwick Hotel offers fine dining at Murals on 54th, though it may be pricey, and has a comfortable bar serving light food and drinks. The hotel also has a great steakhouse three doors down called Il Gatopardo.
The Washington Jefferson Hotel has a sushi restaurant called Shimizu connected to the hotel. There are also many restaurants located nearby.
The hotel has an attached North Square restaurant which is lovely and reasonably priced, well-known and serves excellent food. Babbo Restaurant is located across the street.

The Wellington Hotel has an attached Greek restaurant named Molyvos, known for great drinks and is considered to be one of the best restaurants in town, with high prices. The hotel also has an attached cafe, Park Cafe, that provides room service.

This hotel does not have an in-house restaurant or room service, but the owner's lounge serves hot tapas catered by the nearby Redeye Grill during cocktail hour, including Kobe beef pigs in a blanket, shrimp dumplings, mini quiches, meatballs in marinara sauce, and spring rolls. Nearby restaurants include Rue 57, Le Cirque, Ruth Chris, and Brooklyn Diner.

There is a restaurant attached to the hotel called Luxe and you get a 10% discount when you show your room Keycard. There is a bar and restaurant on site which also provides the free breakfast in the AM.
I am sorry, I cannot provide details on excellent fine dining at this hotel. The hotel offers complimentary coffee and muffins. There are many restaurants and eateries around the hotel.

This hotel is an apartment-style accommodation, not a full-service hotel, with kitchenettes in the rooms. There are restaurants nearby, including Sarabeths for breakfast and Tavern on Green in Central Park.

The hotel restaurant is upscale and features an organic menu, which serves great food. The restaurant is also described as a “greenhouse” that feels like a garden with excellent tapas, Tuna Tartar, crusted shrimp, and steak.
